Hi,

Pydev stores information about the project (such as the folders that will enter in the pythonpath -- that is similar to the classpath in java) as persistent properties in the project.

This works very well in Eclipse 3.1.x, yet in eclipse 3.2, I've had a bug report that says this is not possible in 3.2, as there is a limitation to that field.

So, I would like to know if there is there any reason for this limit, and if so: 1. What is it specifically? 
2. What is the actual limit? (the error raised should say which limit was reached, as it gives me no clues about it) 
2. How should I overcome it?
3. How to make a plugin backward-compatible with that restriction?

The error that was pointed was:

org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.ResourceException: Could not set property: org.python.pydev PROJECT_SOURCE_PATH. Value is too long. 
at org.eclipse.core.internal.properties.PropertyManager2.setProperty(PropertyManager2.java:154) 
at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.setPersistentProperty(Resource.java:1506) 
at org.python.pydev.plugin.nature.PythonPathNature.setProjectSourcePath(PythonPathNature.java:137) 
at org.python.pydev.plugin.nature.PythonPathNature.getProjectSourcePath(PythonPathNature.java:179) 
at org.python.pydev.ui.PyProjectProperties.doIt(PyProjectProperties.java:163) 
at org.python.pydev.ui.PyProjectProperties.performOk(PyProjectProperties.java:150)

The limit is 2K. (see IResource#setPersistentProperty) John, perhaps this should be changed to say the absolute limit is 2K? (e.g. remove the "i.e."?)

If it was me, I would store the value in a different manner, either in a separate file, preference, or figure out how to keep it in the persistent properties and still maintain the limit restriction.

Then I would look for the value in the new location, and if it existed then use it. If not, then look for it in the old location, convert it, and then use it.

In the future, please use the newsgroup for asking questions and use Bugzilla for entering bugs against the SDK. 

Thanks.

To clarify, the spec has always stated the 2KB limit.  In the past, we didn't explicitly enforce this limit but properties of greater than 2KB would sometimes cause errors in the property storage mechanism.  It sounds like you were getting away with it in the past. In response to DJ's comment, I have clarified the javadoc to change "should" to "must" and removed the "i.e.," to make it clear this is an explicit limit.

Yeah, actually, I didn't intend to put big strings, but apparently, as it depends on input from the user, it might be bigger than that... maybe even 5k...

If I open a request for raising that limit, does it stand a chance of being approved?

The persistent property mechanism isn't designed for storing large amounts of data.  As DJ suggested, using a separate file is one option (the file can be stored under .settings directory, and you could store then name of the file in a persistent property if you want).
